tom,

thanks for the repsonse. is it possible for me to borrow a few minutes of
your time for a very short discussion of how heritrix might fit with what
we're considering??

if i were in cambridge/boston, i'd try to bribe you with a lunch!!

it appears that heritrix might be useful for an app that we're considering,
but given that it's in java, and our java skills are limited, we don't want
to go down the wrong path. but if heritrix will do what we need, with less
overall development time, and in a more efficient manner, then we'll come up
to speed with regards to the java learning curve..

however, we also recognize that your time is incredibly pressed today,
giving your house closing! right now, we're just trying to actually talk to
someone who understands the heritrix app to get a better understanding as to
whether or not it would be helpful for our goals.

thanks for any help/assistance that you can provide.

regards

bruce douglas
bedouglas@...
(925) 866-2790

ps.
essentially, we want to create an app that would be directed towards the
registrar sites of various university/college websites. the app would
return/extract information from the websites to be stored in a database.
basically we're looking at class schedules.

our initial understanding of heritrix is that we can "feed" it urls, and
that it will extract the page content for the various urls/sites. we would
then need to write a "reader" app that would parse the returned content for
the information for our purposes.

on the surface, this would appear to be a lot more efficient than creating
100's of different perl scripts.

thanks!

-----Original Message-----
From: Tom Emerson [mailto:Tree@...]
Sent: Friday, May 28, 2004 6:38 AM
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [archive-crawler] Heritrix - use...


Kristinn Sigurdsson writes:
[...]
> Michael's suggestion of datamining the generated ARC files (compiled
running
> an unmodified Heritrix) would get around the whole Java issue.

I will be releasing an updated version of my (C++) libarc library that
includes an application called "dumparc" that allows you to dump
individual members from the ARC file based on the URL.

You can, of course, use the library directly to mine the file: this
may be the solution to the problem: you can mine the ARC files without
mucking about extending Heritrix.

See http://www.sourceforge.net/projects/libarc.

We're closing on a house today, so I'm a bit distracted ;-). But I should
release the updated library sometime this weekend.

    -tree
